Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: FRG: Understanding and Controlling Active Fluids through Modeling, Simulation, and Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soft active materials are collections of particles, cells, or molecules that are capable of converting chemical energy from their environment into motion and mechanical stresses. Examples include swimming microorganisms, cellular extracts, biological polymers, and molecular motors, as well as a wealth of synthetic particles designed to mimic biological systems. These active systems, which have generated considerable excitement over the last decade in many disciplines from engineering to physics to applied mathematics, evince behaviors that are fundamentally different from traditional passive materials, and their understanding is just beginning to illuminate long-standing problems in biology and to suggest new engineering devices. This research project aims to use experiments, modeling, and simulations, to further enhance understanding of a variety of active materials. The project will also involve training through research involvement of postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduates.

The aim of this project is to use a combination of modeling, mathematical analysis, numerical simulations, and experiments to explore the dynamics of archetypal active fluids as their microstructural components interact with obstacles, walls, and each other. Computational and coarse-grained models will explore the interaction of microswimmers, individually and collectively, with boundaries and obstacles. Microfluidic environments will be fabricated to explore how active particle transport is affected and controlled by boundaries and obstacles, and tools of shape optimization will be used to guide the design. Specialized particles will be fabricated to elucidate different aspects of active matter. New types of active matter will be explored, both by considering modifications in particle-scale activity and system-scale confinement. These investigations will include detailed and coarse-grained computational models of recently synthesized active fluids in which immersed microtubules interact through motor-protein cross-linking and pulling, as well as a new active matter system in which particle activity couples to interfacial forces to drive large-scale flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The still emerging field of active matter has generated considerable excitement over the past 15 years, with promising applications for a wide range of engineering and biological systems. Active particles and fluids evince behaviors that are fundamentally different from those of equilibrium systems, including the emergence of spontaneous flows, unusual transport properties and rheological behaviors. Our Focused Research Group aimed to further the basic understanding of these systems using a combination of modeling, analysis, computation, and experiments, with special focus on the interaction of active fluids with obstacles and boundaries and on the control of transport and dynamics by geometrical constraints.

We have developed new experimental systems that illuminate how active particles can self-assemble into functional superstructures, and swim next to walls and in background flows. This work has been done in collaboration with materials chemists at NYU with whom we have synthesized chemically actuated particles with varying proportions and placements of platinum and gold. In one study, we created "tripartite" active particles which do not swim but do generate flows in the surrounding fluid that let them interact with other particles. We showed collections of such particles could form stable stair-case shaped "rotors" that spin like miniature washing machines, or form two-particle "T-swimmers" that swim unidirectionally.

We believe that the electric fields that drive fluid flow are localized around the joins of the particle's two metallic components, and so varying the location of the join can change the flows. In this way we have created different types of swimming active particles, such as Pullers (like bacteria), Pullers (like swimming algae), and Neutrals (like paramecia) all within the same system. Using fabricated microfluidic devices, we have shown, for example, that like bacteria, our chemically powered swimmers naturally swim upstream in an imposed flow -- this is called rheotaxis -- and that Pullers are better at this than others.  

To understand this, we developed a variety of simulations and mathematical models. One basic simulation model used so-called "blobs" which arise from a low-order discretization of shape and boundary conditions for a body immersed in a Newtonian fluid. One can include the effect of actuation, walls, and thermal fluctuations. We used this to create virtual versions of our chemically powered swimmers, and achieved very good agreement with our experiments on nearly all fronts. Our model showed that rheotactic ability was determined by localized high/low pressure nodes along the swimmer surface, and that Pullers performed the best, as experiments showed. This study has now given us develop design principles for creating swimmers that greater or lesser affinity to swimming near surfaces, aiding in their use in directed transport.Further, we have developed reduced models that explain some of the statistical properties of locomotion observed during rheotaxis.

We also investigated how these active particle microswimmers interacted with shaped obstacles in their environment. In the absence of such obstacles, these microswimmers will wander around their environment, changing their swimming direction randomly as they are re-oriented by colllisions of solvent molecules. However, if the obstacles are tear-drop shaped and laid out in arrays, then the particles can be made to swim, in a statistical sense, in a single direction. That is, they can be shown where to go which is a good design goal. We also developed a mathematical theory that predicted the best way to lay out these arrays, so as to maximize the orienting of the swimmers, as well as predicting what were the best obstacle shapes. Some of these shapes were very non-intuitive, and we intend to recreate them in the lab.

In other work, we have developed new computational methods for efficiently simulating large suspensions of active particles. One major advance has been the creation of efficient and accurate means of handling particle collisions. Collisions are handled, or avoided, by using inter-particle repulsive force fields, which puts a heavy constraint on the time-step used to move the system forward. Our method relies instead on a so-called complementarity problem that constrains the geometry of particle assemblies as they evolve under the Stokes equations, with little constraint on time-step. We have applied this to study active suspensions of dividing and swimming particles, to simulate the evolution of large biopolymer/motor-protein assemblies, and to demonstrate the emergence of crystalline order in assemblies of active Stokes rotors.
